p: More than half the world’s 7.5 billion people live in cities a number projected to grow by a further 2.5 billion people by 2050 and cities account for around 85% of global economic activity ( 1). In Europe, approximately 73% of people live in urban areas ( 1). It is increasingly recognised that the design, operation and governance of cities are crucial for achieving goals on sustainability and population heath particularly in areas such as responses to climate change and policies relating to energy, housing, transportation and food ( 2– 4). Urban living brings many environmental challenges, such as pollution, road injury, noise and social isolation ( 2, 5), as well as opportunities for health, especially in the context of the low carbon transition ( 6– 8). Well-planned urban development is crucial for meeting many of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) ( 9), the objectives of the Paris Agreement on climate change ( 10), and the New Urban Agenda ( 11).
